title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.1 Dispersion

Also called “spread”

How spread out or dispersed are the observations?
Only applies to numeric (interval or ratio) variables

Several measures of dispersion

Depend on scale type and variable distribution
Minimum and maximum, percentiles, standard deviation

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.2 Minimum and maximum



Minimum


min(gap_2007$lifeExp, na.rm = TRUE)

[1] 39.613

min(gap_2007$pop, na.rm = TRUE)

[1] 199579

min(gap_2007$gdpPercap, na.rm = TRUE)

[1] 277.5519




Maximum


max(gap_2007$lifeExp, na.rm = TRUE)

[1] 82.603

max(gap_2007$pop, na.rm = TRUE)

[1] 1318683096

max(gap_2007$gdpPercap, na.rm = TRUE)

[1] 49357.19

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.3 Percentiles

Value below which some percentage of observations lie

67th percentile: 67% of observations have values below this value
Median is the 50th percentile: 50% below (and 50% above)
Quartiles divide into 4 parts: 25th, 50th, 75th percentiles
Standardized tests: 97th percentile means you scored higher than 97% of people taking the test

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.5 Standard deviation (& variance)

Spread around the mean
Same units as the variable

Unlike variance, with is \(SD^2\)

Influenced by extreme values
Mathematically: \(\sqrt{\frac{\sum (X_i - \overline{X})^2}{n-1}}\)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.6 Presenting location & dispersion

Symmetric distribution

Mean \(\pm\) standard deviation
Median (25th to 75th percentile)
Median (min, max)

Asymmetric distribution

Median (25th to 75th percentile)
Median (min, max)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.7 Presenting


Code
lifeexp_perc <- quantile(gap_2007$lifeExp, c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1))
lifeexp_sd <- sd(gap_2007$lifeExp, na.rm = TRUE)
lifeexp_mean <- mean(gap_2007$lifeExp, na.rm= TRUE)
ggplot(data = gap_2007, aes(x = lifeExp)) + 
  geom_histogram(bins = 30, color = "grey80")

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.8 Presenting: Mean plus/minus 1 SD


Code
ggplot(data = gap_2007, aes(x = lifeExp)) + 
  geom_histogram(bins = 30, color = "grey80") +
  annotate("pointrange", x = lifeexp_mean, y = 5, 
            xmin = mean(gap_2007$lifeExp) - lifeexp_sd,
            xmax = mean(gap_2007$lifeExp) + lifeexp_sd,
            size = 1.5, linewidth = 1.5, color = "red") +
  ylab("count")

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.9 Presenting: Median, 25th, 75th %iles


Code
ggplot(data = gap_2007, aes(x = lifeExp)) + 
  geom_histogram(bins = 30, color = "grey80") +
  annotate("pointrange", x = lifeexp_perc[3], y = 5, 
            xmin = lifeexp_perc[2],
            xmax = lifeexp_perc[4],
            size = 1.5, linewidth = 1.5, color = "red") +
  ylab("count")

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
5.1 In-class activities

Look at some data and variables

Think about what type(s) of variables they are

Examine central tendency and dispersion for the variables

Present the best values to describe the data

Start to think about variable distributions and plots

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
1.1 Learning objectives

Advanced plotting

Color, size, opacity
Annotations
Changing themes, axis labels, re-ordering categories
Complex and combined plots

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.1 Perception

Data is encoded in graphics

How can we make it easier for people to understand?
What are humans good (and bad) at?

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
section: 2.2 What are we good (and bad) at?
text:
2.2 What are we good (and bad) at?

Good: Comparing position and length

Scatterplots, bar plots

Good: Color!

Use color to highlight, identify, group
Caveats: Colorblindness, contrast, accessibility

Bad: Comparing areas, volume, curvature

Pie charts

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.1 Data

library(gapminder)
data(gapminder)
gap_2007 <- gapminder %>% filter(year == 2007)
head(gap_2007)

# A tibble: 6 × 6
  country     continent  year lifeExp      pop gdpPercap
  <fct>       <fct>     <int>   <dbl>    <int>     <dbl>
1 Afghanistan Asia       2007    43.8 31889923      975.
2 Albania     Europe     2007    76.4  3600523     5937.
3 Algeria     Africa     2007    72.3 33333216     6223.
4 Angola      Africa     2007    42.7 12420476     4797.
5 Argentina   Americas   2007    75.3 40301927    12779.
6 Australia   Oceania    2007    81.2 20434176    34435.

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.1 “color” and “fill”

Some objects have a “color” attribute

This is the color for the whole object

Some objects have both “color” and “fill” attributes

“color” is the outline color
“fill” is the “filled in” color

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.2 Built-in colors in R

http://sape.inf.usi.ch/quick-reference/ggplot2/colour
https://r-charts.com/colors/
Type colors() in the Console for a list of all colors in R

Use the color’s name

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.3 Specific colors: Cedars-Sinai

Red

RGB: 220, 30, 52
HEX: #dc1e34

Grey

RGB: 118, 119, 122
HEX: #76777a



CS_red <- "#dc1e34"
CS_grey <- "#76777a"

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.4 Create a color palette

Color-blind friendly colors from https://jfly.uni-koeln.de/color/


color_blind_friendly <- c("#E69F00", "#000000", "#56B4E9", "#009E73", 
                          "#F0E442", "#0072B2", "#D55E00", "#CC79A7")



Check your plot for color-blind-friendliness

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.5 Change colors manually


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = continent)) +
  geom_bar(color = "black", 
           fill = "pink")

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.6 Change colors manually


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = continent)) +
  geom_bar(color = CS_grey, fill = CS_red)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.7 Colors based on a variable


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap,
           y = lifeExp, 
           color = continent)) +
  geom_point()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.8 Colors based on a variable (CB)


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap, 
           y = lifeExp, 
           color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_color_manual(values = color_blind_friendly)











scale_color_manual() for color
scale_fill_manual() for fill

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
5.1 Change line width


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = continent)) +
  geom_bar(color = "black", 
           fill = "pink", 
           linewidth = 1.5)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
5.2 Change point size


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap, 
           y = lifeExp, 
           color = continent)) + 
  geom_point(size = 4)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
5.3 Change opacity of points


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap, 
           y = lifeExp, 
           color = continent)) + 
  geom_point(size = 4, alpha = 0.3)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
6.1 annotate() layer

General function to add different types of annotations

"text"
"rect"
"segment"
"pointrange"

Also specify location of the annotation

x, y
xmin, ymin, xmax, ymax, xend, yend

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
6.2 Add some text


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap, 
           y = lifeExp, 
           color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  annotate("text", 
           x = 30000, y = 60, 
           label = "Some text here")

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
6.3 Add a rectangle


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap, 
           y = lifeExp, 
           color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  annotate("rect", 
           xmin = 20000, xmax = 40000, 
           ymin = 50, ymax = 70)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
6.4 Useful annotation


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap, 
           y = lifeExp, 
           color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  annotate("text", 
           x = 40000, y = 73, 
           label = "Countries with \nhigh GDP per capita and \nhigh life expectancy") +
  annotate("rect", 
           xmin = 30000, xmax = 50000, 
           ymin = 75, ymax = 83, 
           alpha = 0.2)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
7.1 labs() layer

All the labels in the plot

Title, subtitle, caption
Legend title
X and Y axis labels

Still supports older versions: xlab(), ylab(), ggtitle()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
7.2 Title and subtitle


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap, 
           y = lifeExp, 
           color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "This is the title",
       subtitle = "This is the subtitle",
       caption = "And here's a caption")

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
7.3 Title and subtitle


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap, 
           y = lifeExp, 
           color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Scatterplot of life expectancy vs GDP per capita",
       subtitle = "There is a nonlinear relationship",
       caption = "Data: gapminder package, year 2007")

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
7.4 Axis and legend labels


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap, 
           y = lifeExp, 
           color = continent)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "GDP (per capita)",
       y = "Life expectancy (years)",
       color = "The continents")

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
8.1 Themes

Built-in themes: theme_classic(), theme_grey(), etc.
Packages to change theme

ggthemes: 538, WSJ, Economist
bbplot: BBC

Make your own theme: Branding
Change theme for whole document

e.g., theme_set(theme_classic()) in setup chunk

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
8.2 Theme elements

If you know the name of the part you want to change, you can change it

https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/theme.html

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
8.3 Theme elements

Change color of outer background to green

theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "green"))

Change inner background to white with medium grey border

theme(plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white", colour = "grey50"))

Change axis label text to blue

theme(axis.text = element_text(colour = "blue"))

Remove the legend

theme(legend.position = "none")

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
8.4 Limits, ticks, etc.

Adjust the axis limits, labels, or ticks for continuous variable

scale_x_continuous() and scale_y_continuous()

Adjust the axis limits, labels, or ticks for discrete variable

scale_x_discrete() and scale_y_discrete()

Adjust just the limits

xlim() and ylim()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
9.1 Default order for factors


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = continent)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
section: 9.2 Re-order factor levels in the plot
text:
9.2 Re-order factor levels in the plot


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = reorder(continent, 
                       pop, 
                       fun = median))) +
  geom_bar()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
section: 9.3 Re-order factor levels in the plot
text:
9.3 Re-order factor levels in the plot


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = reorder(continent, 
                       lifeExp, 
                       fun = median), 
           y = lifeExp)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
9.4 Re-order and other things


gap_2007_americas <- gap_2007 %>% 
  filter(continent == "Americas")
ggplot(data = gap_2007_americas, 
       aes(x = country,
           y = lifeExp)) +
  geom_col()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
9.5 Re-order and other things


ggplot(data = gap_2007_americas, 
       aes(x = country,
           y = lifeExp)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
9.6 Re-order and other things


ggplot(data = gap_2007_americas, 
       aes(x = reorder(country, 
                       lifeExp, 
                       fun = mean),
           y = lifeExp)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
9.7 Alternative: Rotate axis text


ggplot(data = gap_2007_americas, 
       aes(x = reorder(country,
                       lifeExp, 
                       fun = mean),
           y = lifeExp)) +
  geom_col() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, 
                                   hjust=1))

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.1 Index plot (Manhattan plot)


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = 1:nrow(gap_2007), 
           y = pop)) +
  geom_point()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.2 Index plot with labels


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = 1:nrow(gap_2007), 
           y = pop)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_text(aes(label=as.character(country)),
            hjust = 0, nudge_x = 2)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.3 Index plot with labels


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = 1:nrow(gap_2007), 
           y = pop)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_text(aes(label=ifelse((pop > 500000000), 
                             as.character(country), 
                             '')),
            hjust = 0, nudge_x = 2)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.4 Bells and whistles version


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = 1:nrow(gap_2007), 
           y = pop)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_text(aes(label=ifelse((pop > 500000000), 
                             as.character(country), 
                             '')),
            hjust = 0, nudge_x = 2) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 500000000, 
             color = "blue", 
             linetype = "dashed") +
  annotate("text", 
           x = 50, y = 850000000, 
           label = "China and India have notably larger populations") +
  annotate("rect", 
           xmin = 20, xmax = 75, 
           ymin = 1000000000, ymax = 1400000000, 
           alpha = 0.2) +
  labs(title = "Most countries have populations below 500 million",
       x = "Country number (index)",
       y = "Population")

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.5 Add rugs to a scatterplot


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap, 
           y = lifeExp)) + 
  geom_point(size = 4, alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_rug()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.6 Add rugs to a scatterplot


ggplot(data = gap_2007, 
       aes(x = gdpPercap, 
           y = lifeExp)) + 
  geom_point(size = 4, alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_rug(sides = "tr")

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.7 Lollipop plot


ggplot(data = gap_2007_americas, 
       aes(x = country,
           y = lifeExp)) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, 
                                   hjust=1, 
                                   vjust = 0.5)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_segment(aes(x = country, 
                   xend = country, 
                   y = 0, 
                   yend = lifeExp))

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.8 Lollipop plot


ggplot(data = gap_2007_americas, 
       aes(x = country,
           y = lifeExp)) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, 
                                   hjust=1, 
                                   vjust = 0.5)) +
  geom_point(size = 4) +
  geom_segment(aes(x = country, 
                   xend = country, 
                   y = 0, 
                   yend = lifeExp))

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.9 Raincloud plot

Allen, M., Poggiali, D., Whitaker, K., Marshall, T. R., van Langen, J., & Kievit, R. A. (2019). Raincloud plots: a multi-platform tool for robust data visualization. Wellcome open research, 4.
Install ggrain package

Or use custom scripts in the article

Dot plot + box plot + (half) violin plot

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.10 Raincloud plot


library(ggrain)
ggplot(gap_2007,
       aes(x = continent,
           y = gdpPercap)) +
  geom_rain()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.11 Raincloud plot


library(ggrain)
ggplot(gap_2007,
       aes(x = 1,
           y = gdpPercap)) +
  geom_rain(color = "black",
            fill = "forestgreen",
            alpha = 0.5) +
  coord_flip()

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
10.12 Raincloud plot


library(ggrain)
ggplot(gap_2007,
       aes(x = 1,
           y = gdpPercap)) +
  geom_rain(color = "black",
            fill = "forestgreen",
            alpha = 0.5) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(x = "", y = "GDP (per capita)") +
  scale_x_continuous(labels = NULL, 
                     breaks = NULL)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
11.1 Final thoughts

ggplot creates layers

Make your plot a layer at a time

Keep perception in mind

What are we good at seeing and processing?

Use color carefully

And sparingly

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
11.2 Label your axes (meaningfully)!

https://xkcd.com/833/

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
12.1 In-class activities

Make some plots

Some of them will be ugly
Let’s try to fix them

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
12.2 Next week

Sample vs population

Conceptual: Statistical inference

Probability and distributions

Sampling distributions

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
1.1 Learning objectives

Compare and contrast point estimates and interval estimates
Construct confidence intervals
Interpret confidence intervals

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.1 Sample vs population







flowchart LR
  A(Population) --> B{Sampling}
  B{Sampling} --> D[Sample]







Sample from a population







flowchart RL
  C{Inference} --> A(Population)
  D[Sample] --> C{Inference}







Make inference from sample back to population

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.2 Sampling distribution

Probability distribution
Quantifies the uncertainty in sampling from a population

Sample isn’t representative of the whole population
Sampling variability in the test statistic
Across all samples from this population, how variable can we expect the test statistic to be?

Standard error is the standard deviation of the sampling distribution

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.3 Sampling distribution

Sampling distribution depends on

Population distribution (sometimes)
Sample size
Test statistic (e.g., mean, regression coefficient)

In last week’s lab, we demonstrated the central limit theorem

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.4 Last week

Different population distributions

Normal, Bernoulli, binomial, Poisson

Sample 10000 times from each population

With different sample sizes: \(n = 10, 50, 100\)

Calculate sample mean (\(\bar{X}\)) for each sample

Examine distributions of means

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.9 Central limit theorem

Regardless of the population distribution

the sampling distribution of the mean
follows a normal distribution

\(\bar{X} \sim \mathcal{N}(mean=\mu, variance=\frac{\sigma^2}{n})\)

as \(n \rightarrow \infty\)

Can happens very quickly: often \(n \ge 30\)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.1 Point estimates

Single number estimate of the population value

Sample mean
Sample variance
Mean difference
Correlation coefficient

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.2 Estimation methods: Point estimates

Sample estimate
Maximum likelihood
(Ordinary) least squares: “OLS regression”
(Weighted) least squares

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.3 Maximum likelihood: Conceptual

Likelihood function based on the distributions of the variable(s)

Likelihood is similar to probability

Doesn’t have some properties

Likelihood of different potential parameter values (e.g., means)
Maximum likelihood estimates are the parameter estimates that are most likely given the data

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.4 Maximum likeihood: Figure


Maximum likelihood estimate is found at \(\mu = 15.4\)


Figure 2 from Enders, C. K. (2005). Maximum likelihood estimation. Encyclopedia of statistics in behavioral science.

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.1 Estimation methods: Interval estimates

Known formulas for some situations
Monte Carlo simulation
Resampling methods: bootstrap, jackknife (leave one out), etc.
Other computational methods

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.2 Why an interval?

Point estimate is almost certainly wrong

e.g., single mean from a single sample

Point estimates are random variables

Random variables have a distribution
Distributions tell us about probability
What are the most likely values?

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.3 Normal distribution

Remember: Sampling distribution is normal

Sample means follow a normal distribution
If we want to talk about this sample mean in the context of all sample means, then we can use the sampling distribution

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.4 Aside: \(z\)-scores

\(z\)-scores are scores on a standard normal distribution

\(\mathcal{N}(0,1)\)

Mean = 0
Variance = standard deviation = 1
Often called “standardized scores”: Subtract mean, divide by SD

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.5 (Standard) Normal: mean = 0, SD = 1


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = c(-4, 4)), aes(x)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "line",
                xlim = c(-4, 4)) +
  xlim(-4, 4)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.6 Symmetric around the mean


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = c(-4, 4)), aes(x)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "line",
                xlim = c(-4, 4)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "area",
                fill = "steelblue",
                xlim = c(0, 4)) +
  annotate("text", x = 0.8, y = 0.1, label = "50%", color = "white", size = 6) +
  annotate("text", x = -0.8, y = 0.1, label = "50%", size = 6) +
  xlim(-4, 4)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.7 Proportion for each standard deviation


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = c(-4, 4)), aes(x)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "line",
                xlim = c(-4, 4)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "area",
                fill = "steelblue",
                xlim = c(-3, -2)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "area",
                fill = "steelblue",
                xlim = c(-1, 0)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "area",
                fill = "steelblue",
                xlim = c(1, 2)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "area",
                fill = "steelblue",
                xlim = c(3, 4)) +
  annotate("text", x = -3.5, y = 0.05, label = "0.13%") +
  annotate("text", x = -2.5, y = 0.1, label = "2.14%") +
  annotate("text", x = -1.5, y = 0.05, label = "13.59%") +
  annotate("text", x = -0.5, y = 0.2, label = "34.13%", color = "white") +
  annotate("text", x = 0.5, y = 0.2, label = "34.13%") +
  annotate("text", x = 1.5, y = 0.05, label = "13.59%", color = "white") +
  annotate("text", x = 2.5, y = 0.1, label = "2.14%") +
  annotate("text", x = 3.5, y = 0.05, label = "0.13%") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -3, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -2, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -1, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 1, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 2, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 3, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  xlim(-4, 4)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.8 Between -1 SD and +1 SD: 68.26%


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = c(-4, 4)), aes(x)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "line",
                xlim = c(-4, 4)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "area",
                fill = "steelblue",
                xlim = c(-1, 1)) +
  annotate("text", x = 0, y = 0.1, label = "68.26%", color = "white", size = 6) +
  annotate("text", x = 2.5, y = 0.1, label = "15.87%", size = 6) +
  annotate("text", x = -2.5, y = 0.1, label = "15.87%", size = 6) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -3, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -2, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -1, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 1, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 2, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 3, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  xlim(-4, 4)

text:

ggplot(data.frame(x = c(-4, 4)), aes(x)) +

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.10 95% between -1.96 SD and +1.96 SD


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = c(-4, 4)), aes(x)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "line",
                xlim = c(-4, 4)) +

                geom = "area",
                fill = "steelblue",
                xlim = c(-1.96, 1.96)) +

  geom_vline(xintercept = -3, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -2, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -1, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 1, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 2, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 3, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  xlim(-4, 4)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.11 99% between -2.326 SD and +2.326 SD


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = c(-4, 4)), aes(x)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "line",
                xlim = c(-4, 4)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "area",
                fill = "steelblue",
                xlim = c(-2.326, 2.326)) +
  annotate("text", x = 0, y = 0.1, label = "99%", color = "white", size = 6) +
  annotate("text", x = 3, y = 0.05, label = "0.5%", size = 6) +
  annotate("text", x = -3, y = 0.05, label = "0.5%", size = 6) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -3, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -2, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -1, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 1, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 2, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 3, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  xlim(-4, 4)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.12 Confidence intervals

Interval estimate of likely values for an estimate

Sample mean is 52.1, but the population mean is unlikely to be exactly that
Range of values in which the population mean exists

Leverage normal distribution of sampling distribution

Use proportion of distribution between different values

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.13 \(100 \times (1-\alpha)\%\) CI for mean

\([\bar{X} - z_{1-\alpha/2}\ \sqrt{\frac{\sigma^2}{n}}, \bar{X} + z_{1-\alpha/2}\ \sqrt{\frac{\sigma^2}{n}}]\)

\(z_{1-\alpha/2}\ \sqrt{\frac{\sigma^2}{n}}\): margin of error
\(\bar{X}\): sample mean
\(\alpha\): probability of type I error (probability in the tails)
\(z_{1-\alpha/2}\): \(z\)-score corresponding to a specific \(\alpha\)
Example: \(95\%\) CI: \(\alpha\) = .05, \(z_{1-\alpha/2}\) = 1.96

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.14 Percentiles


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = c(-4, 4)), aes(x)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "line",
                xlim = c(-4, 4)) +
  stat_function(fun = dnorm,
                geom = "area",
                fill = "steelblue",
                xlim = c(-1.96, 1.96)) +
  annotate("text", x = 0, y = 0.1, label = "95%", color = "white", size = 6) +
  annotate("text", x = 3, y = 0.05, label = "2.5%", size = 6) +
  annotate("text", x = -3, y = 0.05, label = "2.5%", size = 6) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -3, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -2, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = -1, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 1, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 2, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 3, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.3) +
  xlim(-4, 4)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.15 Percentiles from qnorm() function

Percentile: proportion of distribution to the left of a score
For a 95% CI, you do not want the 95th percentile

2.5% in the left tail, 95% in middle, 2.5% in right tail
97.5th percentile (95 + 2.5 = 97.5) provides the \(z\)-score you want



qnorm(0.975)

[1] 1.959964



Default is mean = 0, SD = 1 but you can specify different in arguments

e.g., qnorm(0.975, mean = 5, sd = 2)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.16 CI interpretation

One experiment: 95% chance the CI captures the population mean

Don’t say: “95% chance that the population mean is in the CI”
Population value is fixed; CI either captures it or not

Long run: Over repeated versions of the same experiment, \(100 \times (1 - \alpha)\%\) of the intervals will contain the population value

Population value is fixed; CI either captures it or not

Frequentist (vs Bayesian)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.17 CI width

Decreases as \(n\) increases

Because the sampling distribution narrows as \(n\) increases
\(\frac{\sigma^2}{n}\) decreases as \(n\) increases

Increases as population variability increases

Because \(\frac{\sigma^2}{n}\) increases as \(\sigma^2\) increases

Increases as \(\alpha\) decreases

Because the \(z\)-score used increases as \(\alpha\) decreases

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.18 Example: \(95\%\) confidence interval



n <- 50
n

[1] 50

x <- rnorm(n, mean = 5, sd = 2)
datx <- data.frame(x)
meanx <- mean(x)
meanx

[1] 5.405786

sdx <- sd(x)
sdx

[1] 1.998746

varx <- var(x)
varx

[1] 3.994985



\([\bar{X} - z_{1-\alpha/2}\ \sqrt{\frac{\sigma^2}{n}}, \bar{X} + z_{1-\alpha/2}\ \sqrt{\frac{\sigma^2}{n}}]\)
\([5.406 - 1.96 \times \sqrt{\frac{3.995}{50}}, 5.406 + 1.96 \times \sqrt{\frac{3.995}{50}}]\)
\([5.406 - 0.554, 5.406 + 0.554]\)
\([4.85, 5.96]\)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.19 What does it look like?


Code
ci95min <- meanx - 1.96*sqrt(varx/n)
ci95max <- meanx + 1.96*sqrt(varx/n)
ggplot(data = datx, aes(x = x)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = meanx) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = ci95min, linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = ci95max, linetype = "dashed") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(0:10))

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.20 Why is it so narrow?

Shouldn’t it cover 95% of the observations?

NO!!!

Remember: We don’t care about the sample

We care about the population
The confidence interval tells us about the population mean
Relatively narrow band is where we think the population mean is

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
5.1 Hypothesized population mean

Does sample come from population with a mean of [some value]?

Check whether the confidence interval contains [some value]
Yes: It could come from that population
No: We are [some %] confident it doesn’t

Example data: Does it come from a population with mean = 3?

95% confidence interval is \([4.85, 5.96]\)
3 is not in CI: 95% confident that this sample did not come from a population with mean = 3

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
5.2 Compare groups using CIs

Can we compare two groups using their confidence intervals?

Yes, but it’s not intuitive

If CIs don’t overlap

Groups are different

If CIs do overlap

The groups may or may not be different

Check References on course website for “Graphical comparisons”

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
6.1 In-class activities

Construct some confidence intervals
Interpret the confidence intervals in words

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
6.2 Next two weeks

Hypothesis testing

One mean vs hypothesized value
Two means compared to each other

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
1.1 Learning objectives

Interpret tests comparing two unrelated samples
Summarize data using contingency tables
Describe different study designs for contingency tables

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.1 Independent samples tests

Compare means (or medians) from two unrelated samples
Do the two samples come from populations with the same mean?

Is the difference between the two population means 0?

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.2 Independent samples tests

Parametric tests

Independent samples \(z\)-test
Independent samples \(t\)-test (also Welch’s \(t\)-test)

Non-parametric tests

Median test
Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney U test
Chi-square test and Fisher’s exact test (next week)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.3 Independence

Statistical independence

Two events are independent if the occurrence of one event doesn’t impact the occurrence of another event
Knowing about one event tells you nothing about the other event

Independent samples

Individuals in one sample are not related to individuals in the other sample
The two samples are made up of different individuals

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.4 \(z\)-test: Assumptions

Data are continuous (i.e., ratio or interval)
Data are randomly sampled from the population(s)
Data are independent (within and across groups)
Data are approximately normally distributed OR sample size is large enough for normally distributed sampling distribution (central limit theorem)
Population variance (or SD) is known and same in both groups

“Large sample”: population variance estimated by sample variance

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.5 \(z\)-test: Hypotheses

Directional (one-tailed) tests

\(H_0\): \(\mu_1 \le \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 \le 0\)

\(H_1\): \(\mu_1 > \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 > 0\)

\(H_0\): \(\mu_1 \ge \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 \ge 0\)

\(H_1\): \(\mu_1 < \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 < 0\)


Non-directional (two-tailed) tests

\(H_0\): \(\mu_1 = \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 = 0\)

\(H_1\): \(\mu_1 \ne \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 \ne 0\)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.6 \(z\)-test: Test statistic
\[z = \frac{(\bar{X_1} - \bar{X_2}) - (\mu_1 - \mu_2)}{\sqrt{\frac{\sigma^2_1}{n_1} + \frac{\sigma^2_2}{n_2}}}\]

\(\mu_1 - \mu_2 = 0\) (according to \(H_0\))
\(\sigma^2_1\) and \(\sigma^2_2\) are the variances of the two groups
\(n_1\) and \(n_2\) are the sample sizes of the two groups

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.7 \(z\)-test: Example 1

Is resting pulse rate the same for smokers and non-smokers?

One dataset / variable (column) for each group






Code
library(Stat2Data)
data(Pulse)
#head(Pulse)
library(tidyverse)
Pulse_smoke <- Pulse %>% filter(Smoke == 1)
Pulse_nosmoke <- Pulse %>% filter(Smoke == 0)
head(Pulse_smoke)


  Active Rest Smoke Sex Exercise Hgt Wgt
1     82   68     1   0        3  70 225
2     86   68     1   0        2  73 195
3     87   72     1   0        2  70 173
4    102   77     1   0        2  72 200
5     80   67     1   1        2  65 133
6     99   78     1   0        3  71 165





Code
head(Pulse_nosmoke)


  Active Rest Smoke Sex Exercise Hgt Wgt
1     97   78     0   1        1  63 119
2     88   62     0   0        3  72 175
3    106   74     0   0        3  72 170
4     78   63     0   1        3  67 125
5    109   65     0   0        3  74 188
6     66   43     0   1        3  67 140

Is resting pulse rate the same for smokers and non-smokers?

Check out the data




Code
ggplot(data = Pulse_nosmoke, 
       aes(x = Rest)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "red",

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.10 \(z\)-test: Example 4

Is resting pulse rate the same for smokers and non-smokers?

z.test() function from BSDA package



library(BSDA)
ztest <- z.test(x = Pulse_smoke$Rest, 
                y = Pulse_nosmoke$Rest, 
                sigma.x = sd(Pulse_smoke$Rest), 
                sigma.y = sd(Pulse_nosmoke$Rest), 
                alternative = "two.sided")
ztest


    Two-sample z-Test

data:  Pulse_smoke$Rest and Pulse_nosmoke$Rest
z = 2.4394, p-value = 0.01471
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 0.9783252 8.9776121
sample estimates:
mean of x mean of y 
 72.76923  67.79126

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.11 \(z\)-test: Report results

Reject \(H_0\): \(\mu_1 = \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 = 0\)

\(p\)-value < .05
95% confidence interval doesn’t contain 0 (value from \(H_0\))
These two samples came from different populations

Using a two-sample \(z\)-test, we rejected the null hypothesis that the means are equal, \(z\) = 2.44, \(p\) = .01

Smokers and non-smokers have different resting pulse rates

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.12 \(t\)-test: Assumptions

Data are continuous (i.e., ratio or interval)
Data are randomly sampled from the population
Data are independent (within and across groups)
Data are approximately normally distributed OR sample size is large enough for normally distributed sampling distribution (central limit theorem)
Population variance (or SD) is unknown and same in both groups

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.13 \(t\)-test: Hypotheses

Directional (one-tailed) tests

\(H_0\): \(\mu_1 \le \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 \le 0\)

\(H_1\): \(\mu_1 > \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 > 0\)

\(H_0\): \(\mu_1 \ge \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 \ge 0\)

\(H_1\): \(\mu_1 < \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 < 0\)


Non-directional (two-tailed) tests

\(H_0\): \(\mu_1 = \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 = 0\)

\(H_1\): \(\mu_1 \ne \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 \ne 0\)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.14 \(t\)-test: Test statistic
\[t = \frac{(\bar{X_1} - \bar{X_2}) - (\mu_1 - \mu_2)}{\sqrt{\frac{s^2_p}{n_1} + \frac{s^2_p}{n_2}}}\]

where \(s^2_p = \frac{(n_1 -1)s^2_1 + (n_2 -1)s^2_2}{n_1 + n_2 -2}\)

Assumes equal variances and pools (combines)

with degrees of freedom = \(n_1 + n_2 - 2\)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.15 \(t\)-test: Example 1

Is resting pulse rate the same for smokers and non-smokers?

t.test() function from stats package



ttest <- t.test(x = Pulse_smoke$Rest, 
                y = Pulse_nosmoke$Rest, 
                alternative = "two.sided",
                var.equal = TRUE)
ttest


    Two Sample t-test

data:  Pulse_smoke$Rest and Pulse_nosmoke$Rest
t = 2.4294, df = 230, p-value = 0.01589
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 0.9405909 9.0153463
sample estimates:
mean of x mean of y 
 72.76923  67.79126

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.16 \(t\)-test: Report results

Reject \(H_0\): \(\mu_1 = \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 = 0\)

\(p\)-value < .05
95% confidence interval doesn’t contain 0 (value from \(H_0\))
These two samples came from different populations

Using a independent samples \(t\)-test, we rejected the null hypothesis that the means are equal, \(t(230)\) = 2.43, \(p\) = .02

Smokers and non-smokers have different resting pulse rates

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.17 Welch’s \(t\)-test: Unequal variances
\[t = \frac{(\bar{X_1} - \bar{X_2}) - (\mu_1 - \mu_2)}{\sqrt{\frac{s^2_1}{n_1} + \frac{s^2_2}{n_2}}}\]

with degrees of freedom = something much more complicated

May be fractional

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.18 Welch’s \(t\)-test: Example

welch <- t.test(x = Pulse_smoke$Rest, 
                y = Pulse_nosmoke$Rest, 
                alternative = "two.sided",
                var.equal = FALSE)
welch


    Welch Two Sample t-test

data:  Pulse_smoke$Rest and Pulse_nosmoke$Rest
t = 2.4394, df = 31.721, p-value = 0.02049
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 0.8198241 9.1361131
sample estimates:
mean of x mean of y 
 72.76923  67.79126

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.19 Welch’s \(t\)-test: Report results

Reject \(H_0\): \(\mu_1 = \mu_2\) or \(\mu_1 - \mu_2 = 0\)

\(p\)-value < .05
95% confidence interval doesn’t contain 0 (value from \(H_0\))
These two samples came from different populations

Using a Welch’s \(t\)-test, we rejected the null hypothesis that the means are equal, \(t(31.721)\) = 2.44, \(p\) = .02

Smokers and non-smokers have different resting pulse rates

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.21 Non-parametric tests

Non-parametric versions of \(z\) or \(t\)-test for 2 independent samples

Median test
Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney U test (or Mann-Whitney or Mann-Whitney-Wilcoxon)

Differences in median (technically, “location”)
Mann-Whitney is a somewhat better test

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
2.22 Non-parametric tests



Median test



Code
library(coin)
median_test(Rest ~ as.factor(Smoke), data = Pulse)



    Asymptotic Two-Sample Brown-Mood Median Test

data:  Rest by as.factor(Smoke) (0, 1)
Z = -0.88412, p-value = 0.3766
alternative hypothesis: true mu is not equal to 0




Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney test



Code
wilcox.test(Rest ~ as.factor(Smoke), data = Pulse)



    Wilcoxon rank sum test with continuity correction

data:  Rest by as.factor(Smoke)
W = 1967, p-value = 0.02746
alternative hypothesis: true location shift is not equal to 0

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.1 Contingency tables

Cross-tabs, summary tables, 2x2 table

Relationship between two (or more) categorical variables
Each cell is a frequency for that combination

Sex and Smoke from the Pulse dataset



Code
smoke_sex <- table(Pulse$Sex, Pulse$Smoke)
colnames(smoke_sex) <- c("Non-smoker", "Smoker")
rownames(smoke_sex) <- c("Male", "Female")
smoke_sex_margins <- addmargins(smoke_sex)
smoke_sex_prop_margins <- addmargins(prop.table(smoke_sex))
smoke_sex


        
         Non-smoker Smoker
  Male          105     17
  Female        101      9

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.6 Marginal probability

Marginal probability: Probability of \(X\) or \(Y\), collapsing over the other

What is the distribution of \(X\), ignoring \(Y\)?
What is the distribution of \(Y\), ignoring \(X\)?

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.7 Marginal probability

Start with frequencies










 
\(Y\) = 1: No smoke
\(Y\) = 2: Smoke
 




\(X = 1\): Male
\(n_{11} = \color{red}{105}\)
\(n_{12} = \color{red}{17}\)
\(n_{1+} = \color{blue}{122}\)


\(X = 2\): Female
\(n_{21} = \color{red}{101}\)
\(n_{22} = \color{red}{9}\)
\(n_{2+} = \color{blue}{110}\)


 
\(n_{+1} = \color{blue}{206}\)
\(n_{+2} = \color{blue}{26}\)
\(n = \color{blue}{232}\)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.8 Marginal probability

Divide each value by \(n\): The total sample size










 
\(Y\) = 1: No smoke
\(Y\) = 2: Smoke
 




\(X = 1\): Male
\(p_{11} = \color{red}{0.45}\)
\(p_{12} = \color{red}{0.07}\)
\(p_{1+} = \color{blue}{0.53}\)


\(X = 2\): Female
\(p_{21} = \color{red}{0.44}\)
\(p_{22} = \color{red}{0.04}\)
\(p_{2+} = \color{blue}{0.47}\)


 
\(p_{+1} = \color{blue}{0.89}\)
\(p_{+2} = \color{blue}{0.11}\)
\(p = \color{blue}{1}\)




\(\color{red}{Joint}\) probabilities sum to 1
\(\color{blue}{Marginal}\) probabilities for rows sum to 1
\(\color{blue}{Marginal}\) probabilities for columns sum to 1

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.9 Conditional probability

Often, \(X\) is an explanatory variable, \(Y\) is an outcome variable

But it doesn’t need to be

Conditional probability: Probability of \(Y\) at a given value of \(X\)

When \(X = 1\), what is the distribution of \(Y\)?
When \(X = 2\), what is the distribution of \(Y\)?

Conditional probability is the \(\color{red}{joint~value}\) divided by the \(\color{blue}{marginal~value}\) for that value of \(X\)

It is conditional on that value of \(X\)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.10 Conditional probability









 
\(Y\) = 1: No smoke
\(Y\) = 2: Smoke
 




\(X = 1\): Male
\(n_{11} = \color{red}{105}\)
\(n_{12} = \color{red}{17}\)
\(n_{1+} = \color{blue}{122}\)


\(X = 2\): Female
\(n_{21} = \color{red}{101}\)
\(n_{22} = \color{red}{9}\)
\(n_{2+} = \color{blue}{110}\)


 
\(n_{+1} = \color{blue}{206}\)
\(n_{+2} = \color{blue}{26}\)
\(n = \color{blue}{232}\)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
3.11 Conditional probability









 
\(Y\) = 1: No smoke
\(Y\) = 2: Smoke
 




\(X = 1\): Male
\(n_{11} = \color{red}{105}\)
\(n_{12} = \color{red}{17}\)
\(n_{1+} = \color{blue}{122}\)


\(X = 2\): Female
\(n_{21} = \color{red}{101}\)
\(n_{22} = \color{red}{9}\)
\(n_{2+} = \color{blue}{110}\)


 
\(n_{+1} = \color{blue}{206}\)
\(n_{+2} = \color{blue}{26}\)
\(n = \color{blue}{232}\)






When \(X = 1\) (male):

\(P(no\ smoke) = \frac{\color{red}{105}}{\color{blue}{122}} = 0.861\)
\(P(smoke) = \frac{\color{red}{17}}{\color{blue}{122}} = 0.139\)




When \(X = 2\) (female):

\(P(no\ smoke) = \frac{\color{red}{101}}{\color{blue}{110}} = 0.918\)
\(P(smoke) = \frac{\color{red}{9}}{\color{blue}{110}} = 0.082\)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.1 Fixed vs random

The marginal frequencies of a contingency table can be either fixed or random

Fixed: Chosen by the researcher

e.g., Collect data on 50 men and 50 women

Random: Vary depending on the sample

e.g., Collect data on gender in the sample

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.2 Why do we care?

Probability = random divided by fixed

If there are no fixed marginals, we can’t calculate a probability

Ratio = random divided by random

We can always calculate ratios (e.g., odds ratios)

What is “fixed” is what you can “condition on”

What are probabilities “out of”?

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.3 Why do we care?

Design of the contingency table determines

What is conditioned on
What are probabilities (and what are just ratios)
How you can talk about the relationship in the table
What statistical tests you can perform

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.4 Types of study designs

Three study designs with different fixed and random marginals

Cross-sectional (or multinomial)
Retrospective
Prospective (or product binomial)

title: Introduction to Biostatistics

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.9 Smoke and Sex example

What type of study design was this?

Multinomial: Total \(n\) is fixed
Retrospective: Smoke is fixed
Prospective: Sex is fixed




Code
smoke_sex_margins


        
         Non-smoker Smoker Sum
  Male          105     17 122
  Female        101      9 110
  Sum           206     26 232

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.10 Measures of relationship

Any design

Odds ratio
Test of independence

Prospective design only

Difference in proportion
Relative risk
Odds ratio
Test of independence

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.11 Difference in proportion

If we assume it is a prospective design re: Sex




Male

\(P(smoke) = \frac{\color{red}{17}}{\color{blue}{122}} = 0.139\)




Female

\(P(smoke) = \frac{\color{red}{9}}{\color{blue}{110}} = 0.082\)





Difference in proportion = \(0.139 - 0.082 = 0.058\)

A man is 5.8 percentage points more likely to be a smoker than a woman

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.12 Relative risk

If we assume it is a prospective design re: Sex




Male

\(P(smoke) = \frac{\color{red}{17}}{\color{blue}{122}} = 0.139\)




Female

\(P(smoke) = \frac{\color{red}{9}}{\color{blue}{110}} = 0.082\)





Relative risk = \(\frac{0.139}{0.082} = 1.703\)

A man is 1.703 times more likely to be a smoker than a woman

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.13 Odds ratio
\[odds(smoke) = P(smoke)/P(no\ smoke)\]



Male

\(P(smoke) = \frac{\color{red}{17}}{\color{blue}{122}} = 0.139\)
\(odds = \frac{0.139}{0.861} = 0.162\)




Female

\(P(smoke) = \frac{\color{red}{9}}{\color{blue}{110}} = 0.082\)
\(odds = \frac{0.082}{0.918} = 0.089\)





\(odds\ ratio = \frac{0.089}{0.162} =
0.55\)

The odds of a woman smoking is 0.55 times the odds of a man smoking

title: Introduction to Biostatistics
text:
4.14 Independence

Do the observed frequencies match what we’d expect if the variables were unrelated or independent?




Observed



Code
smoke_sex


        
         Non-smoker Smoker
  Male          105     17
  Female        101      9




Expected (independence)



Code
library(epitools)
expected(smoke_sex)


        
         Non-smoker   Smoker
  Male    108.32759 13.67241
  Female   97.67241 12.32759
